results.headline: An Album About Healing, Made in a Wounded Land

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Under African Skies

results.summary_short: In “Under African Skies,” the filmmaker Joe Berlinger recounts the controversy surrounding Paul Simon’s album “Graceland.”

results.headline: Crawling Backward in Time Into Haunted Real Estate

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Road

results.summary_short: “The Road” conjures a hushed, supernatural universe covering two decades after three joy-riding teenagers disappear at night.

results.headline: A Vampire Thirsty and Bewildered

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Dark Shadows

results.summary_short: Johnny Depp plays Barnabas Collins in this comedy from Tim Burton (their eighth movie together), based on the soap opera from the 1960s and ’70s.

results.headline: Maddening Mind Game With a Methodical Archivist

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of You Are Here

results.summary_short: “You Are Here” is an unsettling visual inquiry, with a methodical archivist as a sleuth, into the nature of consciousness.

results.headline: Midwives to a Peace Process, Where Church and Mosque Coexist

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Where Do We Go Now?

results.summary_short: In a Middle Eastern village, where Christians and Muslims coexist, the women are bent on keeping their hotheaded husbands from starting a religious war.

results.headline: First Handcuffs Lock Them Together, Then Love

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Tonight You're Mine

results.summary_short: “Tonight You’re Mine,” filmed at an actual rock festival, is a meet-cute romantic comedy that manages to feel fresh and lively.

results.headline: Pregnant Technophile in Transit

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Small, Beautifully Moving Parts

results.summary_short: In “Small, Beautifully Moving Parts,” a pregnant technophile in Los Angeles sets out for an uninvited reunion with her mother, currently residing off the grid in the Arizona desert.

results.headline: French Thriller’s Potpourri of Crooked Cops, Gangsters, Drugs and a Hostage

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Sleepless Night

results.summary_short: In “Sleepless Night,” a corrupt police officer must return the cocaine he nabbed from a vicious dealer in order to release his son from the dealer’s sweaty clutches.

results.headline: The Multidimensional Fate of a 1912 Schiele Portrait

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Portrait Of Wally

results.summary_short: “Portrait of Wally” is a documentary on the Third Reich’s art thefts and their aftermath, spotlighting the fate of Egon Schiele’s 1912 oil painting of his mistress.

results.headline: Under the Spell of a Bombshell

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Nobody Else but You

results.summary_short: In the sardonic neo-noir “Nobody Else but You” an amateur gumshoe discovers a dead woman who had a lot in common with Marilyn Monroe. Obsession and detective work follow.

results.headline: Husband Seeks Affair With His Wife as She Was

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Nesting

results.summary_short: “Nesting” centers on a young couple in their 30s who are worried that the spark and sense of adventure have gone out of their marriage.

results.headline: Detours on the Road to a Family Reunion

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of I Wish

results.summary_short: In “I Wish” the director Hirokazu Kore-eda spins an elliptical tale of two young brothers trying to reunite their parents.

results.headline: Young Girl With a Gun Goes to Vegas

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Hick

results.summary_short: In “Hick,” when a young girl decides to leave her Nebraska home for a glamorous life in Las Vegas, she enters an American heartland jumble of dangers and snares.

results.headline: Daughter and Mother, Chasing Adulthood

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Girl In Progress

results.summary_short: “Girl in Progress” is a teenager-coming-of-age tale that, by virtue of its self-conscious parody of that genre, turns out to be an unusually smart example of it.

results.headline: Lies, Damned Lies and Literature

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Bonsái

results.summary_short: In Cristián Jiménez’s “Bonsái,” a struggling writer constructs a novel from a tragic first love, but it isn’t clear what is memory and what is fiction.

results.headline: They Use Guns for Anger Management

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of God Bless America

results.summary_short: Bobcat Goldthwait has written “God Bless America,” a film satire that follows a man and a teenage girl who kill the people who offend them.

results.headline: Two Los Angeles Slackers at Responsibility’s Door

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of A Bag of Hammers

results.summary_short: In “A Bag of Hammers,” two Los Angeles slackers and car stealers are called to adult responsibilities.

results.headline: A Writer Who Defied Categorization

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Patience (After Sebald)

results.summary_short: W. G. Sebald, the German-born author of “The Emigrants,” “Austerlitz” and “The Rings of Saturn,” is the subject of a new documentary.

results.headline: Awkward Love Triangle, With Nanny at Center

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of You Hurt My Feelings

results.summary_short: “You Hurt My Feelings” is a fragile sophomore feature that reminds us that watching movies matters more than listening to them.

results.headline: Seven Tickets to India, Please, and Reservations for an Adventure

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Best Exotic Marigold Hotel

results.summary_short: Retirement-age Britons travel to India, where adventures await in the ensemble comedy “The Best Exotic Marigold Hotel.”
